document.docAuthor: Ceríaco, Luis M. P. & Heinicke, Matthew P. & Parker, Kelly L. & Marques, Mariana P. & Bauer, Aaron M.
document.docTitle: A review of the African snake-eyed skinks (Scincidae: Panaspis) from Angola, with the description of a new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the African snake-eyed skinks (Scincidae: Panaspis) from Angola, with the description of a new species

subSection.paragraph: LUIS M. P. CERÍACO 1,2,* , MATTHEW P. HEINICKE 3 , KELLY L. PARKER 3 , MARIANA P. MARQUES 4,2 & AARON M. BAUER 5

paragraph.emphasis: Museu de História Natural e da Ciência da Universidade do Porto , Praça Gomes Teixeira, 4099-002 Porto , Portugal
Departamento de Zoologia e Antropologia (Museu Bocage), Museu Nacional de História Natural e da Ciência, Universidade de Lisboa , Rua da Escola Politécnica 58, 1269–102, Lisboa , Portugal
Department of Natural Sciences, University of Michigan-Dearborn, 4901 Evergreen Road, Dearborn, Michigan 48128, USA

Centro de Investigação em Biodiversidade e Recursos Genéticos (CIBIO), Rede de Investigação em Biodiversidade e Biologia Evolutiva (InBIO), Universidade do Porto , Rua Padre Armando Quintas 7, 4485 –661, Vairão, Portugal
Department of Biology and Center for Biodiversity and Ecosystem Stewardship, Villanova University, 800 Lancaster Avenue, Villanova, Pennsylvania 19085-1699, USA .

subSection.paragraph:
The genus
Panaspis
in Angola is represented by four species, most of them part of taxonomically and nomenclaturally challenging species-complexes. We present a taxonomic revision of the group in the region and describe one new species,
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov.
, endemic to the lowland areas of the Namibe province , southwestern Angola . Phylogenetic analysis using a combination of mitochondrial (16S, cyt b ) and nucleares (RAG1, PDC) markers, as well as morphological and meristic data support the recognition of the new species. In addition, these data support the presence of nominotypical
Panaspis cabindae
,
P. wahlbergi
and
P. maculicollis
in Angola . Reexamination of the Angolan population of
P. breviceps
was based on morphological analysis, as no molecular data from Angola is available for this species. According to our results, this population likely represents the nominotypical form, but due to its complex taxonomic and nomenclatural history and the lack of molecular data, this population needs to be reconsidered when molecular data become available. The description of a new species and revision of the Angolan
Panaspis
contributes to a better understanding of the true species richness of the Angolan herpetofauna, as well as to understanding the major biogeographic patterns of the region. A key to Angolan
Panaspis
species is also presented.

Key words: endemism;
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov.
; southwestern Africa; cryptic species; taxonomy

O género
Panaspis
está representado em Angola por quatro espécies diferentes, na sua maioria fazendo parte de complexos de espécies particularmente desafiantes a nível taxonómico e nomenclatural. Apresentamos uma revisão taxonómica detalhada do grupo na região e descrevemos uma nova espécie,
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov.
, endémica das áreas de baixa elevação da província do Namibe , sudoeste de Angola . Análises filogenéticas utilizando uma combinação de marcadores mitocondriais (16S, cyt b ) e moleculares (RAG1, PDC), bem como dados morfológicos e de escamas, suportam o reconhecimento da nova espécie. Para além disso, os dados suportam a presença em Angola de formas nominotípicas das espécies
Panaspis cabindae
,
P. wahlbergi
e
P. maculicollis
. Novos exames da população Angolana de
Panaspis breviceps
foram realizadas apenas com base em análises morfológicas externas, visto que não existem dados moleculares desta espécie para Angola . De acordo com os nossos resultados, esta população pode representar a forma nominotípica, mas devido à sua complexa história taxonómica e nomenclatural e à inexistência de dados moleculares, a identidade desta população deverá ser novamente revista quando estes dados se encontrarem disponíveis. A descrição da nova espécie e a revisão das restantes espécies de
Panaspis Angolanas
contribuí para um melhor conhecimento dos verdadeiros números da herpetofauna do país, bem como para começar a deslindar os principais padrões biogeográficos da região. Uma chave dicotómica para as espécies que ocorrem em Angola é também apresentada.

Palavras chave: endemismo;
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov.
; sudoeste Africano ; espécies crípticas; taxonomia Zoobank —
Panaspis mocamedensis

lsid: http://zoobank.org:act: C0518A5F-5AA9-45FB-A978-CDF8B4178A1C

The genus
Panaspis Cope, 1868
, whose members are commonly known as African snake-eyed skinks, has been a subject of renewed interest in recent years, with a molecular-based phylogeny (
Medina et al. 2016
), and the description of three new species (
Soares et al. 2018
;
Ceríaco et al. 2018a
;
Kilunda et al. 2019
) in the last three years. The generic allocation of the different species traditionally regarded as members of
Panaspis
sensu lato was a subject of intense debate and different interpretations during the second half of the twentieth century and first years of the present one ( Fuhn 1969 , 1972 ; Perret 1973 , 1975 ; Greer 1974 ;
Schmitz et al. 2005
;
Jesus et al. 2007
;
Medina et al. 2016
). Brief reviews of the taxonomic and nomenclatural histories of
Panaspis
were presented by
Soares et al. (2018)
and
Ceríaco et al. (2018a)
. Currently, the revison of the ge nus by Medina et al. (2016) ,
Panaspis
sensu stricto includes 19 described species, namely
P. africana (Gray, 1845)
,
P . annobonensis Fuhn, 1973
,
P. breviceps ( Peters, 1873 )
,
P. burgeoni ( De Witte, 1933 )
,
P. cabindae (Bocage, 1866)
,
P. duruarum ( Monard, 1949 )
,
P. helleri ( Loveridge, 1932 )
,
P. maculicollis Jacobsen & Broadley, 2000
,
P. massaiensis ( Angel, 1924 )
,
P. megalurus ( Nieden, 1923 )
,
P. namibiana Ceríaco, Branch & Bauer, 2018
,
P. nimbaensis Angel, 1944
,
P. seydeli ( De Witte, 1933 )
,
P. tancredi ( Boulenger, 1909 )
,
P. thomensis Ceríaco et al.
2018 in
Soares et al. 2018
,
P. tsavoensis
Kilunda et al. 2019
,
P. togoensis ( Werner, 1902 )
,
P. wahlbergi ( Smith, 1849 )
, and
P. wilsoni ( Werner, 1914 )
. However, it is also recognized that a considerable number of cryptic species within the genus still await description (
Medina et al. 2016
;
Ceríaco et al. 2018a
;
Kilunda et al. 2019
).

Currently four species of
Panaspis
are recognized for Angola (see
Marques et al. 2018
):
Panaspis breviceps ( Peters, 1873 )
, only known from a few specimens from the escarpment areas of Kwanza Sul and Kwanza Norte provinces, in the Angolan Escarpment;
Panaspis cabindae (Bocage, 1866)
, extending from central Africa to the central highlands in Angola , effectively reaching its southern limit outside of the xeric zone;
Panaspis maculicollis Jacobsen and Broadley, 2000
, entering Angola in the south-eastern province of Cuando-Cubango; and a representative of the
Panaspis wahlbergi
species complex on the central plateau of Angola .

Panaspis cabindae
, which was originally described from the Cabinda enclave, northwestern Angola , is the most widely recorded species of
Panaspis
in the country (
Marques et al. 2018
). The species is known from southwestern Democratic Republic of the Congo , the Cabinda enclave and northern regions of Angola , extending south through the Angolan escarpment, and being present in the lower elevation margins of the escarpment as far south as Capangombe, in Namibe Province (
Marques et al. 2018
). This wide distribution is supported by the molecular evidence presented by
Medina et al. (2016)
, who showed that specimens from Western Democratic Republic of Congo to southern Angola nested together in a well-supported clade.

The first record of
P. maculicollis
for the country was presented by
Conradie et al. (2016)
, based on a single specimen collected in the southeastern tip of Cuando-Cubango Province. The taxonomic identity of this specimen was confirmed by
Medina et al. (2016)
. This remains the only verified record of this species for Angola .

Bocage (1895) was the first to note the presence of
P. wahlbergi
- type animals in the country, based on two specimens from Caconda and Cahata, in the highlands of Huíla and Bié provinces, respectively. Boulenger (1905) reported specimens from an unspecific locality “between Benguela and Bihe” (currently Benguela and Bié provinces). No additional records of
P. wahlbergi
in Angola have been published since these early contributions, but some Angolan specimens assignable to this taxon exist in several natural history collections worldwide. More recently, specimens morphologically assignable to the
P. wahlbergi
species complex were collected in southern Bié Province near Mumbué municipality in June 2019 .
Branch et al. (2019a)
suggested that the Angolan populations of
P. wahlbergi
potentially represented an undescribed species within the broad
P. wahlbergi
species complex, an idea that appears likely in light of the study of
Medina et al. (2016)
, which showed that the species was composed of at least nine cryptic and still undescribed taxa across its entire range.

No records of
Panaspis
exist in the literature from lower elevations of southwestern Angola , namely in the more xeric areas of Namibe Province . In the course of recent herpetological surveys in the country, specimens were collected in Virei and Maungo municipalities, central Namibe Province , which are morphologically most similar to the newly described species
Panaspis namibiana
(a member of the
P. maculicollis
group) known only from the central and northern regions of neighboring Namibia (Ceríaco et al. 2018).

Although
Medina et al. (2016)
assessed some Angolan material, they did not include any Angolan representatives of the
wahlbergi
,
breviceps
or
namibiana
groups. This material is essential to address the questions regarding the taxonomic identity and biogeographic affinities of the Angolan populations of the different
Panaspis
taxa. Taking advantage of the backbone molecular phylogeny provided by
Medina et al. (2016)
and using newly collected molecular, morphological and coloration data, we taxonomically review the Angolan populations of the genus, provide a key for the species in the country, and present new data on its natural history. Our analyses support the distinctiveness of the newly found population of
Panaspis cf. namibiana
from Namibe Province , which we describe as a new species. Some notes on the biogeographic implications of the new findings for both the
Panaspis
group but also overall regional herpetofauna are also presented.

Newly collected specimens were preserved in 10% buffered formalin in the field and were subsequently transferred to 70–75% ethanol. Liver tissue was removed before formalin fixation and preserved in 95% ethanol. For mensural and meristic comparisons, we examined other Angolan
Panaspis
specimens deposited in the collections at California Academy of Sciences ( CAS ), San Francisco, California , USA , Field Museum of Natural History ( FMNH ), Chicago, Illinois , USA ; Museum for Comparative Zoology, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts , USA ( MCZ ), Florida Museum of Natural History ( FLMNH ), University of Florida , Gainesville, Florida , USA ; Carnegie Museum of Natural History (CM), Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania , USA , American Museum of Natural History ( AMNH ), New York , New York , USA ; University of Texas El-Paso Herpetological collection ( UTEP ), El-Paso, Texas , USA ; Port Elizabeth Museum/Bayworld ( PEM ), Port Elizabeth, South Africa , Ditsong National Museum of Natural History ( TM ), Pretoria, South Africa ; Instituto de Investigação Científica Tropical ( IICT ), Lisbon , Portugal ; Museu de História Natural e da Ciência da Universidade do Porto (MHNC-UP), Porto , Portugal ; Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle ( MNHN ), Paris, France ; Naturhistorisches Museum ( NHMW ), Wien , Austria ; and the Natural History Museum ( BMNH ), London, United Kingdom .

Molecular methods. A dataset of partial 16s ribosomal RNA (16S; 552 bp), Cytochrome B ( cytb ; 605 bp), Recombination Activating Gene 1 ( rag1 ; 674 bp), and Phosducin ( pdc ; 442 bp) sequences was generated for molecular phylogenetic analyses ( Table 1 ). For new sequences, DNA was extracted from tissue samples using Qiagen DNeasy Blood and Tissue kits following the manufacturer’s protocol. Amplification of targeted genomic regions was performed in 25 µL reactions under the following cycling conditions: 150 s initial denaturation at 95 °C, followed by 40 cycles of denaturation at 95 °C for 30 s, annealing at 50 °C for 30 s, and extension at 72 °C for 60 s, and a final extension at 72 °C for 150 s. Primers are listed in Table 2 . Amplified PCR products were purified using AxyPrep magnetic beads and sent to the University of Michigan Advanced Genomics Core for sequencing. Resulting sequences were assembled using MEGA X (
Kumar et al. , 2018
). Additonal
Panaspis
sequences representing all major clades identified in Medina et al. (2016) were obtained from GenBank, with
Trachylepis sulcata
serving as the outgroup. Sequences of each gene were aligned using ClustalX (
Larkin et al., 2007
) implemented in MEGA X, using default parameters. Alignments of the protein-coding genes contained no gaps; gaps in the loop regions of the 16s alignment were kept as determined by the ClustalX alignment algorithm.

subSection.paragraph:
Morphological methods. Specimens were measured with a digital caliper to the nearest 0.1 mm . Lepidosis was examined under a stereo-microscope. Scale nomenclature, scales counts and measurements used in the description follow Broadley (2000), Jacobsen & Broadley (2000) ,
Soares et al. (2018)
and
Ceríaco et al. (2018a)
. We measured the following 23 characters: snout–vent length (SVL), from the snout to the vent; tail length (TL), from anal plate to tip of tail, measured only in specimens with complete original tails; head length (HL), from tip of snout to anterior tympanum border; head height ( HH ), from the base of the maxilla to the top of head; head width (HW), at the widest part of the maxilla; eye-diameter (ED); eye-tympanum distance ( ET ); eye-snout distance (ES), from the front of the eye to the tip of the snout; length of the arm (LA); length of the forearm (LFA); length of the leg (LL); length of the foreleg (LFL); distance between limbs (LD), minimum distance between the insertion of the anterior and posterior limbs; number of scale rows at midbody ( MSR ); number of paravertebral scales (SAD), from the nuchal (excluded from count) to base of the tail; number of scales ventrally (SAV), from the mental (excluded from count) to the anal plate (excluded); number of subdigital scales under Finger-IV (LUFF); number of subdigital scales under Toe-IV (LUFT); number of supralabials (SL), with those widened in subocular position indicated between brackets; number of supraciliaries (SC); nature of contact between parietals (CP); nature of contact between frontoparietals (CFP); nature of contact between prefrontals (CPF); nature of contact between prefrontal and preoculars (CPF/PO). Finally, coloration pattern was reported, and high-resolution photographs of preserved specimens taken. These data were compared with relevant literature on the group ( Perret 1973 , 1975 ; Jacobsen & Broadley 2000 ;
Soares et al. 2018
;
Ceríaco et al. 2018a
) and comparative material of congeners occurring in southern and southwestern Africa, namely
P. cabindae
,
P. wahlbergi
,
P. maculicolis
and
P. namibiana
. All specimens examined in this study are listed in the type and additional material sections of each species’ taxonomic account. Locality data are reported in the form of decimal degrees and use the WGS 84 map datum. Older (non-GPS) records are mostly derived from
Marques et al. (2018)
and have been georeferenced using GEOLocate web application (https://www.geo-locate.org). Elevations are all reported as meters above sea level.

Angolan
Panaspis
included in our phylogenetic analysis belong to four separate species ( Fig. 1 ). Angolan representatives for two of these,
P. maculicollis
and
P. cabindae
, were previously included in the data set of
Medina et al. (2016)
. None of the additional samples we sequenced belong to
P. maculicollis
, and this species is still documented in Angola only from Cuando-Cubango in the far southeast. Most of the samples we sequenced are assignable to
P. cabindae
, which is broadly distributed across the western highlands from the far north all the way to Namibe Province in the south, often with little genetic variation among samples. Our analysis provides genetic verification for two other species of
Panaspis
in Angola . One specimen from Bicuar National Park in south-central Angola was tentatively identified as
Panaspis aff. namibiana in
Butler et al. (2019)
but actually represents
Panaspis wahlbergi
. Finally, four samples from Namibe province in southwestern Angola are sister to the recently described species
P. namibiana
. These Namibe samples are genetically distinct, however, displaying 11% pairwise cyt b sequence divergence from
P. namibiana
and 12% or more from other species in the
P. maculicollis
complex. ( Table 3 ).

Mensural and meristic data are presented in Table 4 . Genetic data in combination with morphology lead us to recognize five species of
Panaspis
in Angola , one of which we describe as a new species. We adopt the general lineage species concept ( de Queiroz 1999 ) and recognize species based on a combination of characters suggesting evolutionary independence. The five taxa of
Panaspis
occurring in Angola differ from each other and from other African species, in several consistent morphological characters, and they are identified through the key presented below. Detailed diagnoses for the different forms, as well as extensive nomenclatural reviews, are given in the taxonomic accounts below.

Panaspis breviceps
(

, 317)

The species was described by Peters (1873) as
Euprepes
(
Euprepes Mabuia
)
breviceps
based on specimens from Gabon and “ Kamerun ” [= Cameroon ] collected, respectively, by Henry Hugh Higgins and Anton Reichenow. Two syntypes ( ZMB 6303 from Gabon , Fig. 2 , and ZMB 8017 from “ Kamerun ”] are still extant in the collections of the ZMB . Fuhn (1972) claimed the presence of three additional syntypes in the collections of the BMNH ( BMNH 1902.11.12.9–11). As noted by
Bauer et al. (2003)
, two other specimens from Cameroon ( ZMB 8313), also collected by Reichenow in Cameroon , do not belong to the type series.

subSection.paragraph:
Several other nominal taxa currently considered to be junior synonyms of
breviceps
were subsequently described. Boulenger (1900) described what he considered to be a new species of
Mabuia
[=
Mabuya
] (currently
Trachylepis
), which he named
Mabuia batesi
, from Benito River, in Gabon ( Fig. 3 ). Subsequent revisions placed it into the synonymy of
breviceps
, initially as
Lygosoma breviceps
by Muller (1910) and Schmidt (1919) , and later as
Panaspis breviceps
by Perret (1973) . Werner (1909) described
Lygosoma ( Leiolopisma ) buchneri
based on one specimen collected by Haas on October 1905 from an unspecified locality in Cameroon , while Chabanaud (1917) described
Lygosoma ( Leiolopisma ) auricillatum
based on one specimen collected by Ellenberger on 1911 from Lambaréné, northwestern Gabon ( Chabanaud 1917 ; Fig. 4 ). Müller (1910) relegated
buchneri
to the synonymy of
breviceps
, a decision then followed by Schmidt (1919) and subsequent authors who dealt with the group (e.g. Fuhn 1972 ; Perret 1973 ). However,
auricillatum
was, for some time, absent from the scientific literature, until Perret (1973) noted it in the synonymy of
breviceps
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3— Illustration of the holotype of
Mabuia batesi Boulenger, 1900
. Adapted from Boulenger (1900) .

subSection.paragraph:
A more complex case has been that of
Panaspis togoensis ( Werner, 1902 )
. This species was described by Werner (1902) based on one specimen collected by Arnold Voelschow in “Deustch-Togo (Atakpame)” [= Atakpamé, Togo ]. The taxonomic identity of
togoensis
has historically been problematic, with some authors considering it as a subspecies of
breviceps
( Loveridge 1952 ; Hoogmoed 1980 ), others considering it as incertae sedis ( Fuhn 1972 ), and Perret (1975) even considering it as a junior synonym of
Panaspis kitsoni ( Boulenger, 1913 )
. These taxonomic uncertainties were partially solved by
Schmitz et al. (2005)
and
Medina et al. (2016)
, who demonstrated that
breviceps
and
togoensis
are in fact two well-separated species, both basal to the remaining southern African
Panaspis
. Both
breviceps
and
togoensis
share the morphological character of having movable lower eyelids, which is completely absent from the remaining
Panaspis
species (
P. cabindae
has pre-ablepharine eyes, which consist in a lower eyelid with a large brille and immovably fixed in the raised position but not completely fused to the upper edge of the orbit, as defined by Greer (1974) , but not a complete movable lower eyelid), explaining why different authors had placed these species in different genera.

FIGURE 4— Illustration of the head of the holotype of
Lygosoma ( Leilopisma ) auricillatum Chabanaud, 1917
. Adapted from Chabanaud (1917) .

subSection.paragraph:
This confusion is a good example of the taxonomic doubts surrounding the placement of
P . breviceps
within the group as a whole. The difficulties of determining correct generic placement are evident from the different generic allocations used by the authors who described the species and its synonyms, but it is perfectly summarized by Müller (1910) , who considered
breviceps
as belonging to
Lygosoma
, and noted that “in determining these specimens [of
breviceps
], I was for quite some time in the dark about whether I had a
Lygosoma
or a
Mabuia
in front of me.” Fuhn (1969 , 1972 ), Perret (1973) and Greer (1974) placed the species in
Panaspis
, but Broadley (1989) suggested that the species was a member of the subgenus
Lacertaspis
, within
Leptosiaphos
. It was once again allocated to
Panaspis
by
Schmitz et al. (2005)
. While this decision was followed by
Medina et al. (2016)
, the phylogenetic position of
breviceps
and
togoensis
outside other
Panaspis
, in line with their synapomorphic morphological characters suggests that its generic allocation may change in the future, when new data are gathered.

Despite the doubts regarding its generic allocation, it may be inferred from the data presented by
Medina et al. (2016)
that what is currently considered as
P. breviceps
is clearly composed of two separated lineages, one represented in their study by a single specimen from Byonga, South Kivu, eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo , and another one from Cameroon . It is evident that a revision of Central and Western African
Panaspis
is much needed, not only to solve present taxonomic uncertainties regarding some taxa, but also to determine whether cryptic diversity occurs within the group.

The only records that exist for Angola refer to a series of five specimens from “Congulu”, collected for the BMNH by Karl Jordan (one of the specimens was later exchanged to the MCZ ; Parker 1936 ). Two other specimens were collected by Gerd Henrich in “Roça Canzele” in 1954 for the FMNH (one of the specimens was later exchanged to the MCZ ). Parker (1936) provided limited morphological data about the specimens from Congulu, noting only that the specimens did not “appear to differ from those found in the Cameroon-Gaboon area, though the number of scales about the body [MSR] may be somewhat lower” as “they vary from 30 to 34” while “the known range of
breviceps
(including
batesi Boul.
) is from 32 to 38”. Perret (1973) , after the examination of 80 specimens , presented a similar range of 32 to 38 MSR. The same range was presented by
Trape et al. (2012)
.

Our analysis of a subset of these specimens ( FMNH 74297 – Fig. 5 ; MCZ R- 110306 , 112221 ) did not find any outstanding external morphological differences between the Angolan population and the Central/West Africa populations, except, as already noted by Parker (1936) , a slightly lower number of MSR (see Table 4 ). The morphological similarity and the lack of molecular data from the Angolan population precludes us from testing its relationships with the Central/West African
P. breviceps
populations.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5— Specimen of
Panaspis aff. breviceps
from Roça Canzele, Angola (FMNH 74297). Photo by Joshua Mata.

subSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Panaspis aff. breviceps
can be distinguished from other members of the genus occurring in Angola and surroundings region by having 1) presence of supranasals; 2) movable lower eyelids; 3) frontoparietals separated; 4) dorsum brown, with four very longitudinal stripes composed of white and black dots; 5) presence of a large lateral dark band on the flanks of females and juveniles; 6) 30 to 34 midbody scales rows.

Specimens examined. ANGOLA : Kwanza Norte Province :
30 km W of Camabatela, Roça Canzele [-8.183º, 15.094º, 718 m ] ( FMNH 74297 – Fig. 5 ); MCZ R- 110306 );
Kwanza Sul Province :
Congulu [-10.86667º, 14.28333º, 639 m ] ( MCZ R- 112221 ; BMNH 1936.8.1.625–628).

Habitat and Natural History notes. Nothing is known about the ecology and natural history of this species in Angola . The habitat of the region in which it occurs is characterized by humid fog forests, dominated by
Celtis
,
Albizia
and
Morus
trees in Congulu and a forest and savannah mosaic dominated by
Annona
,
Combretum
,
Piliostigma
trees and
Andropogon
and
Hyparrhenia
shrubs in Roça Canzele (respectively, vegetation type 3 and 13 sensu Grandvaux-Barbosa 1973). Perret (1973) noted that
P. breviceps
is a “common and characteristic” equatorial forest species, that is usually found in humid areas, such as near marshes and streams. According to Perret (1973) females usually produce two, sometimes three, elongated ( 11 mm ) eggs.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6— Distribution map of
Panaspis aff. breviceps
in Angola.

subSubSection.paragraph: Chresonymy (includes only citations unambiguously pertaining to specimens referable to the species, or explicitly stating or depicting its geographic range).

caption.paragraph: TABLE 4. Comparison between the different species of Panaspis occurring in Angola and neighboring Namibia.

tr.th:
Panaspis maculicollis
(data from Jacobsen & Broadley 2000 – non-Angolan material)

Panaspis namibiana
( n = 11) (data from
Ceríaco et al. (2018a)
– Namibian material)

subSubSection.paragraph:
This species was described by Bocage (1866) based on three specimens collected by the Portuguese explorer José Alberto de Oliveira de Anchieta ( 1832–1897 ) in the Cabinda enclave, northwestern Angola . Cope (1868) described a new genus and species
Panaspis aeneus
. The description of this species was problematic as Cope was unable to provide a specific type locality (according to the original description
Habitat. Probably Swan River, Australia ; possibly from South-Western Africa.
), and the holotype is currently lost. The usage of the nomen
aeneus
was short-lived, as the only other reference to
aeneus
as a valid species was that of Boulenger (1887) , when referring to specimens from Angola . The two specimens labelled as
aeneus
by Boulenger (1887) were collected by the London-born Portuguese colonial officer Joaquim John Monteiro ( 1833–1878 ) in the Luanda region . These specimens are still extant in the collections of the BMNH under the accession number 1873.7.28.11 and are unambiguously conspecific with
P . cabindae
.

In his scholarly revision of the herpetofauna of Angola , Bocage (1895) was the first to synonymize
aeneus
with
cabindae
, a decision then followed by all subsequent authors (e.g. Fuhn 1972 ; Perret 1975 ). In the same work Bocage (1895) provided the first illustration of the species, including detailed views of the head scalation ( Fig. 7 ). Despite the unavailability of
aeneus
type material, the original description provides enough morphological data to confidently confirm that it is conspecific with
cabindae
, namely the presence of supranasals, pre-ablepharine eye and frontoparietals separated, diagnostic features of
cabindae
(see below). Due to this lack of ambiguity, a neotype designation for
aeneus
is not needed. The same holds true for
cabindae
itself, as the original type series was destroyed in the fire that engulfed the zoological collections of Museu Bocage, Lisbon, in 1978.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7— Plate with the illustrations of
Panaspis cabindae
and
Panaspis whalbergii
from Bocage (1895) Herpetologie d’Angola et du Congo.Adapted from Bocage (1895) .

subSubSection.paragraph:
The most recent data on the species was provided by
Medina et al. (2016)
who confirmed, through molecular data, that the species extended from southwestern Democratic Republic of the Congo to southwestern Angola ; our sequence data here further fills in the Angolan distribution of the species. Other recent published records include those from Cangandala National Park, Malanje Province , Central Angola reported by
Ceríaco et al. (2016b)
and
Ceríaco et al. (2018c)
.
Marques et al. (2018)
presented and mapped all available records of the species for Angola . Despite being a quite common species in Angola (LMPC pers. obs.), not much has been published about the distriution, natural history, ecology or conservation status of this species.

Diagnosis.
Panaspis cabindae
can be distinguished from other members of the genus occurring inAngola and surroundingsregionbyhaving1)presenceofsupranasals;2)pre-ablepharineeye(asdefinedbyGreer1974);3)frontoparietalsseparated;dorsumcoppery-brown,withfourveryvaguelongitudinalstripesextendingapproximatelytomidbody, and a thin darker band starting on the temporals and extending to midbody; 5) absence of rows of light spots on the neck; 6) absence of a white ventrolateral stripe; 7) 23 to 26 midbody scales rows ( Figs. 8–9 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8— Preserved specimen of
Panaspis cabindae
from Capangombe, Namibe Province, Angola (CAS 264244). Photo by Luis M. P. Ceríaco.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. The species occurs in the southwestern region of Republic of the Congo and the Democratic Republic of the Congo , extending to all parts of northern Angolan and descending south to central and southwestern Angola through the Angolan escarpment ( Fig. 10 ).

Habitat and Natural History notes. The species is found in a wide variety of habitats, from some more coastal,
Euphorbia
and baobab dominated savannahs, in northwestern Angola , to typical Miombo woodland habitats ( Fig. 11 ) in the central plateau of Angola . The species appears to be absent from the more xeric and desertic areas of the southwest of Angola and northwestern Namibia , however it may possibly be found in more humid areas close to the escarpment. The species is active during the day in leaf-litter, but is rarely seen exposed.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9— Live photos of
P. cabindae
from Capangombe, Namibe Province (above, CAS 264244) and near Cassumbe, Bié Province (below, AMB 11696). Photos by Luis M. P. Ceríaco.

FIGURE 10— Distribution map of
Panaspis cabindae
in Angola and neighboring areas of the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Republic of the Congo.

bibRefCitation.author: Jacobsen, N. H. G. & Broadley, D. G.
bibRefCitation.refString: Jacobsen, N. H. G. & Broadley, D. G. (2000) A new species of Panaspis Cope (Reptilia: Scincidae) from southern Africa. African Journal of Herpetology, 49 (1), 61 - 71. https: // doi. org / 10.1080 / 21564574.2000.9650017

subSubSection.paragraph:
This species was described by Jacobsen & Broadley (2000) , based on specimens from northern Limpopo and Mpumalanga provinces of South Africa , northern Botswana , northeastern Namibia , Zimbabwe , southern Zambia and central Mozambique .
Medina et al. (2016)
presented evidence that the central Namibian populations, as well as those from Mozambique and Limpopo represent undescribed species. The central Namibian population was recent- ly described by Ceríaco et al. (2018), while the other lineages await description.
Conradie et al. (2016)
presented the first record of the species for Angola , based on a single specimen collected in the southeastern tip of Cuando- Cubango Province. The taxonomic identity of this specimen was confirmed by
Medina et al. (2016)
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 11— Habitat of
Panaspis cabindae
. Above: Kalandula falls, Malanje Province. Below: River gallery near Cassumbe, Bié Province. Photos by Luis M. P. Ceríaco

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Panaspis maculicollis
can be distinguished from other members of the genus occurring in Angola by the following combination of characteristics: 1) absence of supranasals; 2) ablepharine eye (as defined by Greer 1974 ); 3) frontoparietals fused; 4) dorsum coppery-brown, with a dorsolateral light stripe extending approximately to midbody, and a thin darker band starting on the temporals and extending to midbody; 5) presence of rows of light spots on the neck; 6) absence of a white ventrolateral stripe; 7) 22 to 28 midbody scales rows (usually 26).

Additional material.
ANGOLA : Cuando-Cubango Province :
Cuando Basin [-17.535º, 23.18916º,
983 m
] ( PEM
R 20007
)
.

Distribution. The species is known from the Kalahari sand areas of northeastern Namibia , northern Botswana and western Zimbabwe . In Angola , the species enters the extreme southeastern tip of Cuando-Cubango Province, however it is probable that it is more widespread in the province, and similar habitat extends into Moxico Province ( Fig. 12 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12— Distribution map of
Panaspis maculicollis
in Angola and neighboring areas of Namibia, Zambia and Botswana.

subSubSection.paragraph: Habitat and Natural History notes. A terrestrial species occupying a variety of habitats from rocky or stony hillsides to open woodland/grassland at altitudes of 220-1200 m ( Jacobsen & Broadley 2000 ). In Angola the species is known from the sparse Miombo woodlands from southeastern Moxico .

treatmentCitation.author: Butler, B. O. & Ceriaco, L. M. & Marques, M. P. & Bandeira, S. & Julio, T. & Heinicke, M. P. & Bauer, A. M.

subSubSection.paragraph:
P. wahlbergi
was originally described as
Cryptoblepharus wahlbergi
by Smith (1849) based on specimens from the “Country to the eastward of the Cape Colony,” later restricted to KwaZulu-Natal Province , South Africa , by FitzSimons (1937) . Similar to all other members of the genus, the species has a complex taxonomic history, especially regarding its genetic allocation (for a review of its taxonomic and nomenclatural history see
Schmitz et al. 2005
and
Medina et al. 2016
). The first records of this species for Angola were provided by Bocage (1895) , who noted specimens collected by J.A.O. de Anchieta from Cahata and Caconda, in the higher elevation areas of Benguela and Huíla provinces, respectively. As he had done with
P. cabindae , Bocage (1895)
provided a detailed illustration of Angolan
P. wahlbergi
( Fig. 7 ). Boulenger (1905) referred to this species specimens collected “between Benguella and Bihé” [between what it is currently understood as Benguela and Bié provinces] by the British explorer William John Ansorge ( 1850–1913 ). These are the only published records of the species for Angola , although some other specimens assignable to the species were collected in the country during the twentieth century and deposited in the collections of Portuguese (IICT), North American (CAS, FMNH) and South African (TM) museums. More recently the species has been relocated in the country.
Baptista et al. (2018)
reported the presence of
Panaspis
sp. in theTundavala area.
Butler et al. (2019)
reported one specimen from Bicuar National Park, which they mistakenly labeled as
P. aff. namibiana
. Other specimens were recently collected by the authors LMPC and MPM in southeastern Bié Province .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 13— Preserved specimen of
Panaspis whalbergii
from Bicuar National Park, Huila Province,Angola (CAS 263401).Photo by Luis M. P. Ceríaco.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Both
Marques et al. (2018)
and Branch et al. (2019) referred to the central Angolan populations of
P. wahlbergi
as
P. aff. wahlbergi
, suggesting doubts about its conspecificity with the nominotypical form, and even suggesting that the Angolan population may represent a different taxon (
Branch et al. 2019a
). However, contrary to what
Medina et al. (2016)
demonstrated for the eastern African populations, where a high level of cryptic diversity exists, and to the suspicions of
Marques et al. (2018)
and Branch et al. (2019), our results unambiguously place the central Angolan population as conspecific with nominotypic
wahlbergi
. The presence in the country of additional undescribed
wahlbergi
-like lineages cannot be excluded, as Bittencourt-Silva (2019) recently reported the presence of one of these lineages (“
Panaspis
sp. Katanga 2” sensu
Medina et al. 2016
) in northwestern Zambia , not far from the Angolan border. Specimens from Calombe-Luso, Moxico Province, (IICT 268–1959 and 276–1959) could potentially belong to this lineage as well. Further sampling in the eastern regions of the country is needed to address this possibility.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 14— Live photos of
P. whalbergii
from Bicuar National Park, Huila Province (above, CAS 263401) and near Mumbué, Bié Province (below, AMB 11675). Photos by Luis M. P. Ceríaco.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Panaspis wahlbergi
can be distinguished from other members of the genus occurring in Angola by the following combination of characteristics: 1) absence of supranasals; 2) ablepharine eye (as defined by Greer 1974 ); 3) frontoparietals fused; 4) dorsum coppery-brown, with a broad black lateral band; 5) absence of rows of light spots on the neck; 6) usually a presence of a white ventrolateral stripe, from supralabials to the groin; 7) 24 to 26 midbody scales rows ( Figs. 13–14 ).

Distribution.
Medina et al. (2016)
restricted to Mozambique and northeastern South Africa , but we here extend that distribution into south-central Angola . Historical records from Zimbabwe and Zambia might also represent true
wahlbergi
, potentially connecting the Angolan population to those of Mozambique and South Africa . However, this distribution requires further assessment, as other cryptic lineages may also be present, as evidenced by the recent discovery in northwestern Zambia of one of the Katangan cryptic lineages of
wahlbergi
by Bittencourt-Silva (2019) . In Angola ,
P. wahlbergi
is limited to the central and southern areas of the Angolan plateau, from Benguela Province to Bié ( Fig. 15 ), but is most likely that the species also occurs in the neighboring areas of Moxico and Cuando-Cubango provinces.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 15— Distribution map of
Panaspis wahlbergii
in Angola.

subSubSection.paragraph: Habitat and Natural History notes. The species is found in Miombo Woodlands, usually under leaf-litter, under rocks, or moving through grass ( Fig. 16 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 16— Habitat of
Panaspis wahlbergi
. Above Bicuar National Park, Huíla Province. Below Mumbué, Bié Province. Photos by Luis M. P. Ceríaco

subSubSection.paragraph:
With the exception of
P. cabindae
, the presence of
Panaspis
species in Namibe province has never been noted. According to our molecular data, some
Panaspis
from Namibe province represent a distinct lineage of the
Panaspis maculicollis
species complex, sister to the recently described
P. namibiana
from neighboring Namibia (
Ceríaco et al. 2018a
). Based on the molecular and morphological evidence produced in this study, we herein describe this population as a new species, putatively endemic to the province.

materialsCitation.collectorName: Luis M. P. Ceriaco & Ishan Agarwal & Suzana Bandeira & Pedro Baptista

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype .
FLMNH 187243 (field number
AMB 10652
), unsexed adult, from a river bed, 45 km SW of Virei (-16.11958°, 12.83458°,
523 m
), Namibe Province , Republic of Angola , collected by Luis M. P. Ceríaco , Ishan Agarwal , Suzana Bandeira and Pedro Baptista on
3 December 2016
( Fig. 17–18 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 17— Preserved specimen (holotype) of
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov .
(FLMNH 10652). Photos by Luis M. P. Ceríaco.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov.
can be distinguished from other members of the genus by the following combination of characteristics: 1) absence of supranasals; 2) ablepharine eye (as defined by Greer 1974 ); 3) frontoparietals fused; 4) dorsum coppery-brown, with a dorsolateral light stripe extending approximately to midbody, accompanied by a thinner stripe composed by black dots band starting on the temporals and extending to the base of the tail; 5) presence of rows of light spots on the neck; 6) absence of a white ventrolateral stripe; 7) 23 to 24 midbody scales rows.

Description of the holotype .
Unsexed subadult in good condition, but with a regenerated tail. Arrangement and relative size of head, body and tail scales typical for
Panaspis
. Robust, cylindrical body with well-developed pentadactyl limbs. Fore- and hind-limbs do not overlap when adpressed against the body. SVL 32.6 mm , tail regenerated. Head length 6.2 mm , with relatively acuminate snout (HL 172% HW). Other relevant measurements are presented in Table 5 . Rostral wider than high, and visible from above. Nasals widely separated behind rostral by frontonasal. Frontonasal acuminate anteriorly, wider than long. Nostrils small, set posteriorly in the nasals bordering the postnasal. Prefrontals in contact with one another, almost pentagonal, contacting loreals, first supraocular, and frontal. Two loreals, the posterior margins of the largest loreal bordering the preocular, which is higher than wide. Frontal length shorter than distance between anterior tip of frontal and tip of snout; frontal in contact with prefrontals anteriorly, the first supraocular, and frontoparietals. Frontoparietals fused, in contact with the frontal, three supraoculars, parietals and interparietal. Frontoparietal plus interparietal length 2.2 times length of the frontal. Interparietal pentagonal with visible parietal foramen in anterior part; parietals about the same width of that of the frontoparietals and contacting each other at the anterior point of the interparietal. Parietals in contact. A pair of large, broad nuchals collectively bordered by a total of eight dorsals. Supraoculars three. Supraciliaries four (left side) and four (right side), third largest. Pretemporals two. Tympanum visible, approximately one seventh the height of the eye. Supralabials six, the fifth and sixth being the suboculars. Ablepharine eye. Infralabials five. Postmental bordering five scales (mental, two primary chin-shields, and one infralabial on each side). Ventral scales smooth. MSR 23, SAD 56, SAV 57. Limbs with five digits; scales on soles of hands and feet smooth. Relative length of digits of manus III>IV>II>VI relative length of digits of pes IV>III>II=V>I. Finger-IV scales 9 (right side), Toe-IV scales 15 (right side). Tail long, robust and tapering smoothly.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 18— Live photo of the holotype of
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov .
(FLMNH 10652). Photo by Ishan Agarwal.

subSubSection.paragraph: Both in life and preservative, background color of flanks and upper side of head, neck, dorsum, legs and tail is coppery brown, with a darker dot in the anterior part of each scale. Posteriorly the tail is lighter, with disjunct dark speckles. A beige stripe, less than one scale wide, limited by the dorsal background color above and by a thin stripe of darker brown below (especially evident under the anterior part of eye), extends from the temporals and runs along the insertion of the arms. Areas below the dark brown stripe become lighter, until they reach the ventral side, which is beige. Presence of rows of light spots on the neck. Supralabials light beige anteriorly and posteriorly, with strong coppery brown markings in the middle. This pattern extends to the infralabials. Venter uniformly light-beige, as are the palmar regions of hands and feet.

Variation. Variaton in scalation and body measurements of the paratypes of
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov.
is reported in Table 5 . The majority of the paratypes agree entirely with the holotype , except regarding the contact between the prefrontals, which are separated in paratypes CAS 263325 and 263326.

Comparison with other south and southwestern African
Panaspis
.
As the molecular data provide evidence of the independence of the
P. mocamedensis
sp. nov.
lineage from all other taxa, we here restrict our morphological comparisons to those named congeners occurring in Namibia and Angola . The extreme morphological conservatism of
Panaspis
limits diagnostic characters for most species (except
P. cabindae
and
P. aff. breviceps
) to subtle features, chiefly related to coloration pattern. Comparing
P. mocamedensis
sp. nov.
with
P. cabindae
and
P. aff. breviceps
, the newly described species can be easily distinguished by not having supranasals (present in
P. cabindae
), by having an ablepharine eye (pre-ablepharine eye in
P. cabindae
and completely movable lower eyelids in
P. aff. breviceps
), and by having the frontoparietals fused (divided in
P. cabindae
and in
P. aff. breviceps
). In comparison with
P. wahlbergi
,
P. mocamedensis
sp. nov.
can be distinguished by its coloration, namely by the lack of the broad black lateral stripe and bordering ventrolateral white stripe extending from the supralabials through the ear to the groin (males) or terminating behind the shoulder (females).
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov.
can be distinguished from
P. maculicollis
on the basis of the lack of black patch extending from ear to just beyond the shoulder and by having a smaller count of midbody scale rows ( 23 to 24 in
P. mocamedensis
sp. nov.
versus typically 26 in
P. maculicollis
).
P. mocamedensis
sp. nov.
can be distinguished from the newly described
P. namibiana
on the basis of the presence two or three vertical or diagonal rows of white spots on the neck and by having a smaller count of midbody scale rows ( 23 to 24 in
P. mocamedensis
sp. nov.
versus usually more than 24 in
P. namibiana
).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 5. Measurements (in mm) and scale counts of the holotype and paratypes of
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov.
Abbreviations are the same as those described in Materials and Methods.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. The newly described species is currently only known from central Namibe Province ( Fig. 19 ). It is likely that the species occurs in other regions of the province where appropriate habitat is available, but further sampling is needed to confirm its presence.

Habitat and Natural History notes. The species is terrestrial and is typically found under leaf litter or other debris. It is only known from habitats represented by mosaics of steppes and savannah dominated by Mopane trees and sandy soils ( Fig. 20 ; Grandvaux-Barbosa 1973). Specimens from Virei were captured by day, but CAS 264266 was active under debris well after sunset.

Etymology. The specific epithet “
mocamedensis
” refers to the former name of Namibe Province (Moçâmedes), to which the species is apparently endemic. We propose the English vernacular name “Moçamedes Snake-Eyed Skink” and the Portuguese vernacular name of “Lagartixa da Manta-Morta de Moçâmedes”.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 19— Distribution map of
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov .
in Angola. Star denotes type locality.

FIGURE 20— Mosaics of steppes and savannah dominated by Mopane trees and sandy soils savannah in Maungo, central Namibe Province, where one of the paratypes(CAS 264266) of
Panaspis mocamedensis
sp. nov .
was found. Photo by Luis M. P. Ceríaco.

subSection.paragraph:
The geographical distributions of the different
Panaspis
clades present in Angola are in accordance with the main biogeographic patterns observed in the country (
Marques et al. 2018
;
Huntley et al. 2019
): 1) clear incursions of Central/Western African lineages (
P. cabindae
and
P. aff. breviceps
) through the northern areas of the country, extending considerably south through the more forested areas of the Western Angolan escarpment; 2) intrusions of representatives of southwestern/desert lineages (
P. mocamedensis
sp. nov.
), crossing the Cunene River through the low elevation areas of southwestern Angola ( Namibe province ) and extending coastally towards Benguela province ; and 3) presence of more southern African/Zambezian clades (
P. wahlbergi
and
P. maculicollis
) through the higher elevations/plateau areas of central and southern Angola . Although not confirmed from Angola , the presence of a Katangan lineage of
P. wahlbergi
(“
Panaspis
sp. Katanga 2” sensu
Medina et al. (2016)
, according to Bittencourt-Silva (2018)) on the Zambian side of the northeastern Angolan border, also highlights a fourth pattern, which is depicted by the intrusion of Katangan representatives into Angola through the northwesten and central western areas of the country, a pattern already noted in the recently described
Trachylepis raymondlaurenti Marques, Ceríaco, Bandeira, Pauwels & Bauer (2019)
(
Marques et al. 2019a
). More data are needed to fully address this topic in Angola , and especially to draw the borders (and contact zones), that divide these biogeographic groupings. However, certain areas, such as the abrupt separation between the higher elevation/plateau and the lower elevation/coastal areas in the center and southwestern regions of the country play the role of a barrier.

The Angolan population of
P. aff. breviceps
represents an interesting example of the northern intrusion of Central/West African lineages in the country, a pattern seen in many other herpetological groups (see
Marques et al. 2018
), and recently highlighted by Ernst et al. (2014, 2015). Ernst et al. (2014) recorded the presence of an undescribed species of
Trichobatrachus
in northern Angola . This taxon, morphologically indistinct from
Trichobatrachys robustus Boulenger, 1900
, presented a considerable genetic divergence for the 12S and 16S mitochondrial genes, which may indicate the presence of a cryptic species (Ernst et al. 2014). A similar pattern was also presented by the discovery by the same team of representatives of
Xenopus andrei Loumont, 1983
, in northwestern Angola (Ernst et al. 2015). Similar to the case of
P. breviceps
, the closest population of
X. andrei
lies 2,400 km north, in Gabon . However, the difficult taxonomic and nomenclatural history of
P. breviceps
, combined with the lack of molecular data to support any solid taxonomic decision, precludes us from making any more definitive conclusions as to the true identity of this population. As noted by
Soares et al. (2018)
and
Ceríaco et al. (2018a)
, the extreme morphological conservatism of the genus, makes morphology-only taxonomic decisions highly problematic and prone to errors. Dedicated surveys to the known areas of occurrence of this population are needed to collect additional specimens that will allow its taxonomic revision.

Despite being poorly known,
P. cabindae
is one of the most widespread species in the country. Its distribution extends from southwestern Congo to the Angolan Lunda provinces, and thence to southwestern Angola . The species has little genetic variation across its distribution, especially considering that it extends through quite different habitats, from low elevation areas to some of the higher areas of the Angolan central plateau, and also from the dense tropical forests of the Congo to the fringes of the most xeric areas in Namibe province. Its north to south distribution seems to follow the course of riparian areas and the escarpment, a pattern also seen in some species of the genus
Trachylepis
(Ceríaco et al. in prep.).

On the other hand, both
P. maculicollis
and
P. wahlbergi
are representatives of “Zambezian” species (sensu
Marques et al. 2018
), whose distribution finds its westernmost boundaries in southeastern Angola . The presence of other “Zambezian” species in central and southeastern Angola has already been noted by
Conradie et al. (2016)
and
Marques et al. (2018)
, and it is mainly explained by the somewhat open and homogeneous habitat that extends from the Central Plateau of Angola to parts of Zimbabwe , Mozambique , and northeastern South Africa . This region is situated at altitudes that vary between 1000 and 1500 meters above the sea level and are dominated by Miombo woodlands and savannahs without major geographic barriers, thus allowing the spread of species. Southeastern Angola remains one of the least explored areas in the country (
Conradie et al. 2016
;
Marques et al. 2018
), and it is expected that current and future surveys in the area will contribute to a better understanding of the phylogenetic and biogeographic affinities of the herpetofauna of the region, new species records for the country, and discovery of new species for science.

The distribution of
Panaspis mocamedensis
,
sp. nov.
in Namibe Province is coincident with one of the areas of highest reptile species richness and endemicity in the country (
Roll et al. 2017
;
Marques et al. 2018
). Its phylogenetic affinities to its recently described sister taxon,
P. namibiana
from neighbouring Namibia , suggests that the Cunene River may have acted as a barrier and promoted its separation and consequent speciation. The Cunene River’s role as a barrier is also observed in other herpetological taxa, as in the case of some taxa in the scincid genus
Trachylepis
(Ceríaco et al. in prep.) or in the gekkonid genus
Rhoptropus ( Kuhn 2016 )
. However, the river appears to not have served as a barrier in other groups (
Heinicke et al. 2016
; Butler et al. in prep.), More data, from a wider taxonomic sampling, are needed to better understand the historical role of the Cunene.

The description of
P. mocamedensis
sp. nov.
represents the description of the seventh new species of reptile from the country since 2012, reflecting a steady increase of the numbers of Angolan herpetofauna, especially when compared to the almost five decades of no scientific activity in the country (
Marques et al. 2018
). The descriptions of many additional species from diverse taxonomic groups are currently being prepared by different teams working in the country, which, in combination with the discovery of new first country records, will certainly increase the already rich Angolan herpetological diversity.

As data on demography and other biological data are lacking, the conservation status of Angolan
Panaspis
must be based primarily on distributional data. With numerous localities across a large extent of occurrence, and presumably a large area of occupancy, IUCN Red List guidelines would imply a status of Least Concern for
Panaspis cabindae
and
P. wahlbergi
. These two species are also present in multiple sites within the Angolan protected areas network. The known distribution of
P. maculicollis
, which occurs in Angola marginally, lies within the Luenge-Luiana National Park boundaries, and it is widespread through Zambia , Namibia and Botswana , which also leads to a status of Least Concern. For the newly described endemic,
P. mocamedensis
sp. nov.
, with only two known locali- ties, there is not enough data to infer its conservation status, and, therefore, the species should be considered of Data Deficient status. Due to the taxonomic uncertainties regarding
P. aff. breviceps
, the present data are insufficient to make any proper inference on conservation status.

The present work is a result of the ongoing collaboration between the Instituto Nacional da Biodiversidade e Áreas de Conservação (INBAC) from the Ministry of Environment of Angola and its international partners. INBAC provided institutional and logistical support, as well as the necessary permits for carrying out this research. The “ Angola Ambiente Group”, namely Luis Querido, Rogério Ferreira and António Martins have also helped us in field surveys in Luanda and its vicinities. We also would like to thank Álvaro (“Varito”) Baptista and his team for all the assistance and outstanding support during the field surveys in Namibe and Bié Province . The authors thank the help and support of various museums and their respective curators, collection managers and technicians, who allowed the access to the specimens consulted in this paper, namely Frank Tillack ( ZMB ), Patrick Campbel ( BMNH ), Silke Schweiger and Georg Gassner ( NHMW ) Lauretta Mahlanghu ( TM ), Werner Conradie ( PEM ), David Kirzirian and Lauren Vonnhame ( AMNH ), Jose Rosado ( MCZ ), Lauren Scheinberg ( CAS ), and Alan Resetar and Joshua Mata ( FMNH ).
